definitions.definition: a statement that a person makes, admitting that they are guilty of a crime; the act of making such a statement

examples.text: After hours of questioning by police, she made a full confession.
His confession was extracted under torture.
It's difficult to believe it's a true confession after all her lies.
She made a false confession during the trial which she later retracted.
The court excluded the confession wrongly obtained by the police.
The police forced a confession out of him.
a true confession of a terrible crime
an alleged confession by the defendant

phrases: force a confession out of somebody
get a confession out of somebody

definitions.definition: a statement admitting something that you are ashamed or embarrassed about; the act of making such a statement

examples.text: I've a confession to make—I lied about my age.
I have a confession to make. I read your private emails.
The government made open confession of its inability to cope with the crisis.

phrases: force a confession out of somebody
get a confession out of somebody

definitions.definition: a private statement to a priest about the bad things that you have done; an occasion when you make such a statement

examples.text: The priest heard her confession and granted absolution.
I used to go to confession every Saturday as a child.

definitions.definition: a statement of your religious beliefs, principles, etc.

wordOrigin: late Middle English: via Old French from Latin confessio(n-), from confiteri ‘acknowledge’, from con- (expressing intensive force) + fateri ‘declare, avow’.
